meanings.sent1: Yesterday, it did transpire that the sun rose in the east.
meanings.sent2: It will transpire that the event starts at noon.
meanings.sent3: It transpired that the cat chased its own tail, much to everyone's amusement.
meanings.sent4: As the day unfolded, it transpired like a well-written story.
meanings.sent5: The magic show made it transpire that rabbits can indeed disappear.

meanings.definition: To become known or be revealed
meanings.sent1: The truth will transpire eventually, no matter how hard one tries to hide it.
meanings.sent2: It transpired that the secret was out, causing quite a stir.
meanings.sent3: In the end, it transpired that the missing sock was hiding in the laundry basket all along.
meanings.sent4: The mystery novel made it transpire that the butler was the culprit all along.
meanings.sent5: The detective's keen observation skills made it transpire that the suspect was lying.

meanings.definition: To give off or release moisture through pores or small openings
meanings.sent1: Plants transpire water to stay cool on hot days.
meanings.sent2: It is essential for trees to transpire water to maintain their health.
meanings.sent3: The cactus transpired water slowly, as if it was conserving every drop.
meanings.sent4: The humid room made it transpire that the walls were damp with moisture.
meanings.sent5: The steam from the kettle transpired into the air, creating a warm atmosphere.
